title: How do artists get paid from music streaming?

intro.p1: It is commonly understood that artists make money when their music is being played on streaming platforms like Spotify, Apple Music, Deezer, Pandora, Tidal, YouTube Music, and Amazon Music. But most of us do not know how those payments actually work, which may sometimes lead to some misconceptions. For example, artists do not get a fixed rate for every stream, e.g. $0.00026 per stream<sup>1</sup>, or $0.0037 per stream<sup>2</sup>.
intro.p2: Instead, music recordings royalties are a share of the streaming platforms revenue that is proportional to their commercial use - i.e. when it gets listened to.
intro.p3: Letâ€™s dive in and break down the fundamental principles that dictate how artists get paid from music streaming.

sec1.headline: Artist and Intermediaries
sec1.intro: Let's start by examining who are the players involved in getting the artist's music online and making sure they receive the money they are due.

bloc1.headline: Featuring artist recording royalties
bloc1.p1: A bit of clarification before we start. For every track on a streaming platform, a number of parties may be due a payment, such as the featuring artist, composer, lyricist, publisher, record label etc.
bloc1.p2: In order to keep things simple, this article focuses only on the case of the recording royalties due to the primary/featuring artist(s).

bloc2.headline: Getting Music Online
bloc2.p1: First things first: before any music can be played on streaming platforms it has to get there.
bloc2.p2: Artists do not deal with streaming platforms directly. Instead, they use a distributor who will then take care of getting their music to streaming platforms.
bloc2.p3: In the case that the artist is signed to a record label, the record label may take care of the distribution on behalf of the artist.
